posts.title: I got some of the fantastic FastLED exa
posts.content: I got some of the fantastic FastLED examples (copied and adapted from +Stefan Petrick and +Mark Kriegsman) working on an Adafruit Medium 32x32 RGB LED matrix panel.  I used a Teensy v3.1 and the SmartMatrix shield and library from +Pixelmatix.  More details to come, source available here: https://github.com/jasoncoon/SmartMatrix-FastLED-Examples﻿

posts.title: I_ve tried using a Raspberry Pi, Arduin
posts.content: I've tried using a Raspberry Pi, Arduino Uno, and Arduino Mega to drive my 32x32 RGB LED Matrix from Adafruit, but was unhappy with the color depth and frame rate.  The Teensy v3.1 has a higher clock speed and supports DMA, which the SmartMatrix library uses to drive it at 24-bit color and much higher FPS.  This was my first attempt (back in April), and later replaced the bread board and jumper wires with a SmartMatrix Shield.

posts.title: My latest project has been getting musi
posts.content:
My latest project has been getting music visualization working on the SmartMatrix display.  I tried the Adafruit FFT tutorial for the Teensy, before switching to the Teensy Audio library's FFT.  I'm much happier with the results.

Project and source code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/SmartMatrixSpectrumAnalyzerBasic

posts.content: Using Craig Lindley's Light Appliance sketch as a platform for infrafred remote controlled patterns, I made a few games to run on a SmartMatrix display.  Snake was pretty easy to get working.

posts.title: So, has anyone found an alternative pro
posts.content: So, has anyone found an alternative product that allows a single source to send Bluetooth audio to two receivers simultaneously?

posts.title: I_ve taken a short break from working w
posts.content:
I've taken a short break from working with matrices and wired up an APA102 strip to a Teensy v3.1 and an IR receiver.  Thanks to the FastLED creators and community for making this so much faster and easier, and for sharing your code and ideas!

I picked up this cheap 44 button IR remote, which is a nice, simple way to control the color, pattern, speed, etc: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004IJFAMW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Here's the code, but it's a bit of a mess right now, I will be reorganizing/refactoring soon: https://github.com/jasoncoon/APA102_Teensy_IR

I wrote a simple sketch and a web app to control the pattern, brightness, etc: https://github.com/jasoncoon/SparkRing

posts.content: Another shiny project that could likely benefit from FastLED integration.  All open-source, open-hardware.  Looks like it's using a Spark Core.

link.title: L3D Cube: The 3D LED Cube from the Future

posts.title: I think this is my new favorite pattern
posts.content:
I think this is my new favorite pattern.  Each 'boid' is placed at a random spot at the top of the display.  Its angle of movement is based on simplex noise (from the FastLED library) for its position.  Color cycles through the currently selected palette, which can be changed via the IR remote.

I think I'm translating from angle to velocity incorrectly, as they always move down and to the right, never up or to the left.  Here's the code if you're interested, or can help me figure out what I'm doing wrong: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/blob/master/PatternFlowField.h

posts.title: This pattern is 32 points, each moving_
posts.content:
This pattern is 32 points, each moving up and down independently, with speeds steadily increasing from left to right.  At different times, the pattern produces traveling waves, standing waves, beating, etc.

I've tried several times to convert from using sin() to using FastLED's sin8(), but can never get it working, if anyone has any ideas/suggestions.

The code is here: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/blob/master/PatternPendulumWave.h

posts.title: With a helpful tip from +Stefan Petrick
posts.content: With a helpful tip from +Stefan Petrick, I modified this pattern from using floating-point math to using FastLED 3.1's new beatsin8 function.  It's much simpler now.  Thanks +Mark Kriegsman for the excellent work!

resharedPost.content:
This pattern is 32 points, each moving up and down independently, with speeds steadily increasing from left to right.  At different times, the pattern produces traveling waves, standing waves, beating, etc.

I've tried several times to convert from using sin() to using FastLED's sin8(), but can never get it working, if anyone has any ideas/suggestions.

The code is here: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/blob/master/PatternPendulumWave.h

posts.title: I picked up a fill-able plastic light b
posts.content: I picked up a fill-able plastic light bulb ornament and a small sparkly foam ball that fits inside from a local craft shop.  I cut an opening big enough for a 12 NeoPixel ring and hollowed out the ball, wired up a Teensy (although a Trinket or any small Arduino board would probably work).  Everything fits inside nicely.  Now I'll have to try to fit a battery pack inside...  :)

posts.title: Post
I_ve seen a few people in this communit
posts.content: I've seen a few people in this community make similar lamps, and finally decided to try making my own.  I picked up a cheap lamp at IKEA and wired up an APA102 strip, a Teensy 3.1 and an infrared remote.  I added a few patterns contributed by FastLED members, along with adjustable brightness and color.

posts.title: I wired up the Teensy audio library_s F
posts.content: I wired up the Teensy audio library's FFT to my APA102 LED lamp.  Here's the code: http://git.io/Rz17Ww  I need to find some code for good automatic gain control and/or dynamic range compression.  I'd like it to react well regardless of the volume level.  Anyone have any they'd suggest?

posts.title: Aurora v1.2.1 Pre-release is out with t
posts.content: Aurora v1.2.1 Pre-release is out with the new 'pendulum wave' pattern and a few bug fixes (like the clock not updating).  This release is based on the current code in the master branch.  After a few more days of testing, we'll go ahead and make this the recommended release.  Please let us know if you have any problems, questions, etc.

posts.title: So apparently the BlinkyTile kit usesˇW
posts.content: So apparently the BlinkyTile kit uses WS2822S LEDS, which are wired in parallel and use the DMX protocol.  Luckily, FastLED already supports DMX and it was simple to get running on an Arduino Uno.  I also tried it successfully on a Teensy 3.1.  This is Mark's ColorPalette example.  Thank you Daniel and Mark for all of your hard work at making this easy!

resharedPost.content: A dodecahedron made of BlinkyTiles, running on an Arduino Uno using the FastLED library.  Source code and more information: https://github.com/pup05/BlinkyTileFastLED﻿

posts.title: _Teensy-LC (low cost) is coming in abou
posts.content:
"Teensy-LC (low cost) is coming in about 1 month, featuring a 32 bit Cortex-M0+ processor at 48 MHz, 64K flash, 8K RAM, and a rich hardware peripheral set.... at a retail price of $11.65 (USD)"

"A 5V output buffer is provided for pin 17, to output a 5V logic signal useful for driving WS2812/NeoPixel LED strips."

posts.content: Aurora v1.3 release is ready, with lots of great new patterns and improvements.  A big thanks to community members +J.B. Langston  and +Konstantin Gredeskoul for their contributions!  Please try it out and use the issue tracker on GitHub to report any problems: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/issues

posts.title: +Matt MetsˇBlinkinlabs_ latest blog pos
posts.content:
+Matt Mets Blinkinlabs' latest blog post covers my project to get BlinkyTiles working with FastLED and Arduino-based boards (instead of their Lightbuddy controller, which is a bit more involved to reprogram and add patterns).

They also added a pack of 42 tiles to their shop for $55: http://goo.gl/cXttmJ  I know that seems pricey compared to other LED packages, but you can make some cool LED sculptures pretty easily with them.  Note: I am in no way affiliated with Blinkinlabs.  :)

posts.title: Aurora v1.4 release is ready, with supp
posts.content:
Aurora v1.4 release is ready, with support for the Arduino 1.6.3 and Teensyduino 1.22, new patterns, better palette support, improved TPM streaming mode, bug fixes, and more:

https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/releases/tag/1.4

Please try it out and use the issue tracker on GitHub to report any problems: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/issues

posts.title: In addition to the newly released Auror
posts.content:
In addition to the newly released Aurora v1.4, we're also testing a new 'Update Files' settings item that restarts the SmartMatrix into USB mass storage device mode.  This allows you to load new images, messages, etc onto the SD without having to remove the card.  In my testing on Windows, it automatically reboots into Aurora after 'ejecting' the drive.

Please try it out if you have a chance and let us know if you have any questions or problems.  It's in the new Aurora1.5 branch.  You can just download Aurora.hex and use the Teensy Loader, or follow Louis' instructions to build it yourself.

Aurora v1.5 branch: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/tree/Aurora1.5

Aurora.hex: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/raw/Aurora1.5/bin/Aurora.hex

More information: https://github.com/pixelmatix/JumpToUsbMsdAppWithOffset

posts.title: I recently came across Paul Kourany_s p
posts.content:
I recently came across Paul Kourany's port of Pong Clock (https://github.com/pkourany/RGBPongClock). It's a fork of Andrew Holmes' Pong Clock, which, in turn, is "Inspired by, and shamelessly derived from Nick's LED Projects".

The 2 players automatically win and lose so their scores show the hours and minutes.

Anyway, once I saw it, I knew I had to port it to SmartMatrix/FastLED.  :)

posts.title: 7 hours left on a great project, though
posts.content: 7 hours left on a great project, thought some of you might be interested.  :)  I've used the mono MSGEQ7 boards Peter Easton sells on eBay (http://goo.gl/oyeYqE) and picked up one of his new stereo ones at Maker Faire.  Much smaller and less expensive than the SparkFun shield.

link.title: MSGEQ7 breakout boards by Peter Easton — Kickstarter

posts.title: IKEA LAMPAN lamp with 90 APA102C RGB LE
posts.content: IKEA LAMPAN lamp with 90 APA102C RGB LEDs, driven with a Particle Core and FastLED.  The LEDs are arranged into a 6x15 matrix.  Controlled with a small web app over Wi-Fi.  I'll post some build pics, source code, and more details soon.  Thank you all for the inspiration, and for making this stuff so much easier!

resharedPost.content: Here's my second attempt at a RGB LED lamp, this time a bit smaller and using a Particle Core, which allows easy control over Wi-Fi.  I made a small 2D matrix of LEDs, instead of just a strip like the last lamp.  This allows effects that wrap around the lamp horizontally 360 degrees, in addition to vertical motion.

posts.title: More video and pics, and a peek inside_
posts.content: More video and pics, and a peek inside my latest prototype lamp. Source code and more details: https://github.com/jasoncoon/ParticleCoreMatrixLamp

posts.title: This was my first (and possibly last) a
posts.content:
This was my first (and possibly last) attempt at making a matrix out of strips.  :)  I very strongly dislike soldering LED strips, especially the 144 per meter ones I used for this project.  Any pointers?  I soldered straight break away headers to each end, but had to sacrifice one LED per strip so I had a full pad on each end.

Aside from that, this was a pretty easy build.  There are build notes in the pictures, if you'd like more details.

This was a fairly quick prototype build, I hope to rebuild it, and maybe bring the LEDs closer to the shade for a little less diffusion.

Any suggestions from you build pros out there?

resharedPost.content: More video and pics, and a peek inside my latest prototype lamp. Source code and more details: https://github.com/jasoncoon/ParticleCoreMatrixLamp

posts.title: I can_t decide what to do with these. ˇ
posts.content:
I can't decide what to do with these.  Any suggestions?  I'm thinking about a 3D dodecahedron or icosahedron.  Or maybe a non-grid 2D arrangement, such as a Fibonacci spiral like +Jim Bumgardner's.

I think +Mark Kriegsman's Pride2015 pattern looks pretty fantastic on these, by the way.  Thanks for sharing, Mark!  https://gist.github.com/kriegsman/964de772d64c502760e5 I

posts.title: OK, I_ve test-mounted 100 x 12mm RGB LE
posts.content:
OK, I've test-mounted 100 x 12mm RGB LED pixels on a sheet of cardboard.  I definitely like it so far.  Questions:

Anybody have experience mounting these?  Do you prefer ABS, acrylic, metal, or something else?  1.5mm or 1/16", right?

Advice on the best layout, for when I later try to map to XY and/or polar coordinates?  I ran these in a spiral, from outside to inside, but I'm wondering if zig-zag, or radial from inside out on each spiral arm would be better.

More info, photos & video: https://goo.gl/photos/PKdywS4g8Ngv1umD8

posts.title: PSA_ Micro Center has the (Particle) Sp
posts.content: PSA: Micro Center has the (Particle) Spark Core with Chip Antenna for $24, or with u.FL Connector for $27, in store only.  Almost as cheap as the Photon, but with FastLED compatibility!  Also a small breadboard, and a micro USB cable.  I just picked up a few.  :)

posts.title: I_ve come up with two different ways (s
posts.content:
I've come up with two different ways (so far) to map the spiral arms evenly.  Next up: XY mapping!

Source: https://github.com/jasoncoon/fibonacci/blob/gh-pages/fibonacci.ino#L516

posts.title: Thanks for all of your help! ˇHardware_
posts.content:
Thanks for all of your help!  Hardware is finished, for now.  I'll build something prettier than a black box later.  I'm finally going to start working on different ways of mapping this thing.  :)

I added more build pics, videos, and details to the album: https://goo.gl/photos/PKdywS4g8Ngv1umD8

Source: https://github.com/jasoncoon/fibonacci/blob/gh-pages/fibonacci.ino#L503

posts.title: OK, I have XY mapping working, and it l
posts.content:
OK, I have XY mapping working, and it looks alright, but I feel like I'm doing it wrong.  It's so irregular that I was driving myself crazy trying to get each pixel in its own grid cell.  I finally just divided it up into a 10x10 uniform grid, but that puts multiple pixels in the same cell, so I had to use a three dimensional array (10x10x2).  Many cells don't have any pixels, and some just have one, so I mapped the empty slots to a 101th non-visible pixel (similar to the RGB shades XY mapping).

Anyway, here's the source, feedback welcome, as always: https://github.com/jasoncoon/fibonacci/blob/gh-pages/fibonacci.ino#L656

posts.title: My latest creation. ˇSimilar to my wire
posts.content:
My latest creation.  Similar to my wireless BlinkyTile Dodecahedron, this is built with a Spark Core with Wi-Fi, 48 RGB LEDs, accelerometer/magnetometer, lipo battery, and charger.

Source code: https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/PlasmaSphere

Build details and pics: https://goo.gl/photos/GFF6yLdpjBrtcw666

posts.title: +Mark Kriegsman_sˇfantastically sublime
posts.content: +Mark Kriegsman's fantastically sublime "ColorWavesWithPalettes" pattern running on the Plasma Sphere.  Source: https://gist.github.com/kriegsman/8281905786e8b2632aeb

posts.title: While I am looking forward to creating_
posts.content: While I am looking forward to creating custom patterns specifically for this build, I really appreciate being able to get immediate gratification by using the fantastic patterns shared by this community.  I have yet to find a form-factor on which Mark's ColorWavesWithPalette and Pride2015 do not look amazing.  So far I've tried them on strips, matrices, organic 2D layouts, rings, etc.  Thanks!

resharedPost.content: +Mark Kriegsman's fantastically sublime "ColorWavesWithPalette" pattern running on the Plasma Sphere.

posts.title: Well, I know what my next project is go
posts.content: Well, I know what my next project is going to be...  :)

posts.title: I built these prototypes out of cardboa
posts.content:
I built these prototypes out of cardboard a while back, and have been waiting to share them until I built proper bodies out of wood (which still hasn't happened).  Built three different sizes, each with 60 APA102s: 5.22" small (144/m), 10.44" medium (72/m), and 12.53" large (60/m).  I plan to build them with larger faces to block more direct lighting.  They diffuse very nicely out onto the wall on which they're hung.

I really need to step up my woodworking skills, so I found a local guild that has all the expensive equipment, and classes to learn how to use them.  Now I just need more spare time...  :)

Source: https://github.com/jasoncoon/SparkRing/blob/master/Firmware/spark-ring/spark-ring.ino

resharedPost.content: Clock/circular display built with a Spark Core, syncs time automatically via Wi-Fi.  All you have to do is set the time zone.

posts.title: I finally got a 64x64 display assembled
posts.content:
I finally got a 64x64 display assembled out of four 32x32 panels, and immediately got to work making sure all of my favorite patterns scaled properly.  Spiro is one of my favorites.  :)

Source code: https://github.com/pixelmatix/aurora/blob/sm3.0-64x64/PatternSpiro.h

posts.title: I put a larger diameter face plate on m
posts.content:
I put a larger diameter face plate on my large clock/lamp to better hide the LEDS, and I think it looks much better.  The face is thin and ~13.5" in diameter.  The 1m 60 APA102 LED strip is mounted around a ~12.5" diameter disc.  The Spark Core is inside a hollowed-out section on the back.

I really like Mark's Juggle pattern on it.  I'll be sharing more soon.  Just tell me if you're getting tired of my posts, and I'll cut back.  :)

posts.title: Funny, I was just talking about needing
posts.content: Funny, I was just talking about needing increased light output...  But these are going to be $15 each.  Regardless, I found the design notes very interesting, especially his decision to use 115.2k baud serial instead of the WS28X serial protocol.﻿

link.title: Design | Pixie - the 3W Chainable LED Pixel | Adafruit Learning System

posts.title: I saw someone mention Loomi or IQlight_
posts.content:
I saw someone mention Loomi or IQlight on here, but I can't seem to find the conversation now.  Anyway, I ordered a small puzzle lamp kit and put a Spark Core and two 24 NeoPixel rings in it.  I used a lamp socket to outlet adapter, then a USB power adapter, and a short USB power cable to hang the lamp from the recessed "can" light in the ceiling.

I'm very happy with the diffusion and form, but I'd like it to be brighter and more usable as a lamp replacement.  So of course I plan to put more LEDs inside.  :)  I'd also like to construct something more 3D inside than two rings back-to-back, so I can more fully utilize the volume, get more motion, etc.  Thoughts, suggestions?

PUZZLE LIGHTS: White Modern Lamp Shade (Small):
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00QJ1J5SC

posts.title: Happy Halloween!_Both are lit with Neo
posts.content:
Happy Halloween!

Both are lit with NeoPixel rings and the Fire2012 pattern. One is driven with a Photon, the other with a Gemma. Using cheap rechargeable USB power banks for power.

posts.title: I finally found a use for this set of c
posts.content:
I finally found a use for this set of concentric WS2812B rings: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/RGB-LED-Ring-WS2812-5050-RGB-LED-with-Integrated-Drivers/32372470495.html

I assembled them into new guts for my lamp. The old ones were a little too 2 dimensional (and borrowed from another project). Each of the rings is rotated 90 degrees from the last. They're driven with a Photon.

More pics and details: https://goo.gl/photos/kQZDY4a3qdGYzi8x6

posts.title: I still was not happy with the concentr
posts.content: I still was not happy with the concentric rings of Bloom v2. The LEDs are too far from the shade, and they all just kind of bleed together, making defined patterns impossible. So I decided to try prototyping another idea for getting the LEDs closer to the inside of the shade. I'm definitely liking the results so far. Here's some video: https://youtu.be/RggXoOulBD4?list=PLUYGVM-2vDxIfNUpsjKOf4zyBqYhldaWD

posts.title: I personally contributed to this quite_

posts.content: This looks like an interesting little board.  Anyone tried it out?  Same 8MHz 3.3V ATmega32u4 as the Flora, with built-in USB, JST battery connector, battery charging, and microSD slot, for $22.  If only it were 5V logic, you might not need any level-shifting.  Seems like it'd be great for portable POV projects.

posts.content:
My first FastLED-powered, RGB LED Christmas Tree, with Wi-Fi!  Because why not?!  Controlled with a web app, can change brightness, pattern, etc.  Running Mark's fantastic ColorWavesWithPalettes pattern in this video.  Going to try to come up with some custom palettes and a few other patterns over the next few weeks.

Source: https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/tree

Christmas Tree Light-Show with AllPixel, BiblioPixel, and PixelWeb

posts.title: My wife_s family has a tradition of mak
posts.content:
My wife's family has a tradition of making jewelry trees.  My daughter and her grandparents made one, and I helped add a little color to it.

Built with 30 8mm WS2811 RGB LEDs, a Teensy 3.1, the FastLED library, and an infrared receiver and remote control.

Build pics and details (click the info button on the pics): https://photos.google.com/album/AF1QipMp3wwAzU9HrsRP40a0yCmx8zOzwEGdoiVD8cCB

Source code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/jewelrytree-teensy-ir

posts.title: My first attempt at a spiral matrix. ˇI
posts.content:
My first attempt at a spiral matrix.  I've been playing around with noise, trying to make different fire and lava lamp patterns.  Source code: https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/torch

It's a 4 meter strip of 60/m WS2812B wrapped around a section of 3" PVC pipe, which just barely fits snugly inside a small IKEA KVARNÅ table lamp.  Driven with a Teensy 3.1 and FastLED (of course).  Controlled with an IR remote.

I'm going to try 2.5" PVC pipe next, as I'd like a little more height and more distance between the LEDs and the frosted glass, for more diffusion.

I didn't take any assembly pictures, but will if/when I rebuild it with 2.5" pipe.  Here are a few pics of the top: https://goo.gl/photos/CSTDgXTopRSXpjJA7

posts.title: I wired up a stereo MSGEQ7 board and ad
posts.content:
I wired up a stereo MSGEQ7 board and added a couple of music reactive patterns.

I switched to a thinner section of 2.5" PVC pipe, which makes the spiral taller and provides more distance between the LEDs and the frosted glass for better diffusion. I also added a rolled sheet of vellum paper inside the glass for even more diffusion.

Added a couple more pics: https://goo.gl/photos/CSTDgXTopRSXpjJA7

Source: https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/torch﻿

posts.title: Sorry if this is a double post. ˇI shar
posts.content: Sorry if this is a double post.  I shared this from mobile, and then had someone tell me it didn't show up in the FastLED community.

I wired up a stereo MSGEQ7 board and added a couple of music reactive patterns.

I switched to a thinner section of 2.5" PVC pipe, which makes the spiral taller and provides more distance between the LEDs and the frosted glass for better diffusion. I also added a rolled sheet of vellum paper inside the glass for even more diffusion.

Added a couple more pics: https://goo.gl/photos/CSTDgXTopRSXpjJA7

posts.title: Fibonacci v3D! ˇMy wife requested I bui
posts.content:
Fibonacci v3D!  My wife requested I build a round Fibonacci spiral lamp, so I took a break from working on v2: https://goo.gl/photos/p4i8afc8MCnTVcs69

I ran the LEDs in a slightly different order than v1, so I'll need to redo the XY and spiral maps.  I also plan to create radius and 3D maps, and maybe wire up a MSGEQ7 for audio reaction.

Build pics, with details in the info for each pic: https://goo.gl/photos/ijtXuzpKviSNW9Kv7

Source code (very much a work in progress): https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/fibonacci-v3d

posts.title: Well, what a difference proper mapping_
posts.content:
Well, what a difference proper mapping makes.  I mapped the proper Fibonacci order (radius from the center out) and the spirals, waves, etc, really stand out now.

I still like the smooth spinning effect given by using the physical, unmapped order (pseudo nearest neighbor, from outside in), so I've made variants of several patterns using both.  Mark's Pride2015 pattern also looks especially amazing now: https://youtu.be/4gHrsgkmIo4?list=PLUYGVM-2vDxJLjAv6qwl_FOBu8xzAoJL4

I also completed two different XY maps (much simpler than my previous 3D array attempt), here's a video of some XY based patterns (wipes, noise, fades, waves, fire, etc), with some 1D strip patterns (rainbow, bpm, juggle, twinkles, etc) mixed in: https://youtu.be/k1uY6yGgAB8?list=PLUYGVM-2vDxJLjAv6qwl_FOBu8xzAoJL4

posts.title: Fibonacci v1 is off to a new home, so o
posts.content: Fibonacci v1 is off to a new home, so of course I had to build another.  :)  Version 2 has the same physical layout as v3d, but in a 12" x 12" x 2.5" square white frame with a metal face.  I completed polar mapping, and am working on new patterns that utilize it.  More pics and details coming soon: https://goo.gl/photos/TA2RXFS82G9uapnJA

posts.title: I_m experimenting with different ways o
posts.content:
I'm experimenting with different ways of mapping an +Adafruit Industries DotStar Disk with 255 APA102 RGB LEDs: https://www.adafruit.com/product/2477

I'm using the fantastic polar mapping work by +Adam Haile at +Maniacal Labs LLC, thanks for sharing!  http://maniacallabs.com/2015/05/04/review-code-adafruit-dotstar-disk

I also have it XY mapped, and this video shows alternating Noise patterns using both methods.  The "Polar Patterns" video in the playlist shows some other neat uses of the disk's concentric ring layout.

Driving it with a Teensy 3.2 by +PaulStoffregen, controlled with an IR remote control, and mounted in a round enclosure.

Source code: https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/sol

More pics and details: https://goo.gl/photos/r1iTCG6SSmyAfgbs8

posts.title: The internals are all the same as Torch
posts.content:
The internals are all the same as Torch v1 (240 WS2812, Teensy 3.1, MSGEQ7, IR, etc), but I've upgraded the body to glass and metal.  I hid all the electronics in the base, and used panel mount jacks for power and audio.

I still need to find a good panel mount micro USB jack, and find a better looking small panel mount momentary push button.  Any recommendations?  The black and red plastic ones I've found look completely out of place.  I like these, but don't need the LED: https://www.adafruit.com/product/481

Pics: https://goo.gl/photos/RmBr31cSpFRqYBom8

Source code: https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/torch

posts.title: Finally picked up an ESP8266 and got it
posts.content:
Finally picked up an ESP8266 and got it controlling a small 24 NeoPixel Ring with FastLED, via a web app stored in SPIFFS (on-board flash memory).

The web app is a single page app with separate files for js and css, using jQuery and Bootstrap.  It has buttons for On/Off, a slider for brightness, a pattern selector, and a color picker.  Event handlers for the controls are wired up, so you don't have to click a 'Send' button after making changes.  The brightness slider and the color picker use a delayed event handler, to prevent from flooding the ESP8266 web server with too many requests too quickly.

The only drawback to SPIFFS that I've found so far is uploading the files is extremely slow, requiring several minutes, regardless of how large the files are.  Is it this slow for anyone else, or just me?  It's so slow that I've been just developing the web app and debugging locally on my desktop (with a hard-coded IP for the ESP8266), before uploading to SPIFFS and testing on the ESP8266.

The firmware implements basic RESTful web services using the ESP8266WebServer library.  It can run in connected or standalone access point modes.  Current values are requested with HTTP GETs, and values are set with POSTs using query string parameters.

Thanks to +Juergen Bruegl for sharing your code and inspiring me to take a crack at it myself.  Thanks to +Garrett Durland for pointing out SPIFFS!  And, of course, thank you to +Daniel Garcia and +Mark Kriegsman for getting FastLED working on the ESP8266 and sharing all of your fantastic code!

Source code (firmware and web) is all there.  It's all pretty standard jQuery and Bootstrap.  Let me know if you have any questions, comments, suggestions.

posts.title: My latest project_ Fermat (Lux Phyllota
posts.content:
My latest project: Fermat (Lux Phyllotaxis). It's an 11 inch stainless steel hemisphere with 100 8mm WS2811 RGB LEDs, driven with an ESP8266, and controlled via a web app over Wi-Fi and/or IR remote control. The firmware is nearly identical to my last post on the ESP8266, but with Fibonacci layout mapping and patterns added.

More videos: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUYGVM-2vDxJR3-o5jWMMrj-VdtU3KqAu

Build pics (click the Info button for more details): https://goo.gl/photos/yMJLEGrmUm88v7ym7

Source code:

https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver
https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/fibonacci-v3d

posts.title: After a short break, I_m back with my l
posts.content:
After a short break, I'm back with my latest project: Ducenti (Lux Phyllotaxis). It's very similar to my last project (Fermat), but with twice as many LEDs! It's an 11 inch stainless steel hemisphere with 200 8mm WS2811 RGB LEDs. It's currently driven by a Teensy 3.2, but I'm planning to swap it out for an ESP8266 soon.

I'm using a SN74HCT245N level shifter, TSOP38238 IR receiver, 5V 10A power supply, etc.

More videos: https://youtu.be/_QrlcxV9vOw?list=PLUYGVM-2vDxJ_wbXZH5qWYUxle7hjN0CF

Build pics (sorry, I didn't document this build very well): https://goo.gl/photos/VTCBmkZ8aZh4pSj79

Running code very similar to these projects:

https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver
https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/fibonacci-v3d﻿

posts.content:
I picked up a cheap white styrofoam Jack O' Lantern on clearance at Michaels, and lit it up using a Gemma, 24 NeoPixel ring, and a 3xAAA battery holder. Nothing too fancy, but thought I'd share. :)

posts.title: This looks like a handy little board th
posts.content: This looks like a handy little board that can be soldered inline and powered from a 10mm, 3 pin LED strip.  It's based on the Arduino ProMini (ATmega329P, 5V, 16MHz, 32K flash, 2K SRAM, 1K EEPROM).  It's a little pricey for what it is at $28 + $5 shipping (to US), and doesn't include a micro USB port (requires a serial converter) but definitely a cool form factor.

posts.title: This may seem obvious to some here, but
posts.content: This may seem obvious to some here, but I find it brilliant! I'm currently using the largest inline brick style power supply I can find (5V 15A: https://goo.gl/ljl3Ln). I am ready to step up to a larger open style, but am concerned about the exposed contacts. I was looking for project boxes and stumbled upon this customizable compact cover with a switch, a standard PC power supply socket for the AC input, and XT60 connectors for high amperage DC output (https://goo.gl/iMmnwB).

link.title: Ultimate Power Supply Terminal Cover by mike_mattala

posts.title: My latest project is a 6.5_ white tree_
posts.content:
My latest project is a 6.5' white tree with 250 WS2811 LEDs, an ESP8266 microcontroller, controlled with a web app over WiFi and/or an infrared remote control. Currently at 35 procedural animations using a fully 3D mapped layout (X, Y, and Z axes, plus radius and angle), allowing scrolling and rotating in any direction.

More videos: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUYGVM-2vDxJKi8lgQGImMW3xGfPCup2E

Full write-up with parts list, pics, and details (maybe just short of a full tutorial): https://www.evilgeniuslabs.org/tree-v2.html

posts.title: Post
Today I was honored to deliver a rainbo
posts.content:
Today I was honored to deliver a rainbow tree to the Equality House in Topeka, Kansas, with my daughter and her Girl Scout Troop. We spent the day soldering and learning to use the FastLED library to bring more light and color into the world.

Thank you to Daniel and Mark for creating this library, sharing your genius and inspiration, and starting this community. Thank you to everyone in this community for sharing your inspiring works, and for all of the help and inspiration I've received. Without you all, there's no way this would have been possible.

The Equality House is a symbol of compassion, peace, and positive change. The house, which is painted the colors of the Pride flag, serves as the resource center for all Planting Peace human rights and bully prevention initiatives and stands as a visual reminder of our commitment, as global citizens, to equality for all.

The house is located in Topeka, Kansas directly across from the Westboro Baptist Church hate group.

http://www.plantingpeace.org/equality﻿

posts.title: I got my Christmas present early_ a MP_
posts.content:
I got my Christmas present early: a MP Select Mini 3D Printer from Monoprice: http://www.monoprice.com/product?p_id=15365

They were on sale for $180 on Black Friday, and so far I've been very impressed with the print quality. After reading the review on Hackaday, I was convinced to try one: http://hackaday.com/2016/06/13/review-monoprice-mp-select-mini-3d-printer

I've kept it busy printing custom little LED sculptures. :) More pics and videos: https://goo.gl/photos/F2LRV7gRGQWKkrPe6

posts.title: Post(1)
Post
Here is the PCB and enclosure I_ve been
posts.content:
Here is the PCB and enclosure I've been working on for the Wemos D1 Mini & Pro. It's all THT (through-hole soldering), no SMD (tiny surface mount). It brings out all the pins, and runs D5 - D8 through a level shifter. It should support four parallel sets of three wire LEDs (WS281x), or two sets of four wire LEDs (APA102). It also includes a spot for a large 1000uF capacitor, IR receiver, and data/clock line resistors. I've tested it out pretty thoroughly. One is currently running my 250 LED tree.

I have two spare PCBs (can order more), and I'm waiting on a shipment from Wemos (should be in any day now). Would anyone be interested? Just the PCB? Enclosure? Full kit? Fully assembled? Let me know if you're interested, or if you have any questions, comments, suggestions, etc in the comments. Thanks!

More pics, with details in the comments: https://goo.gl/photos/8b7nrKiCQwB8vZGbA

Update The board and enclosure are now available on Tindie: https://www.tindie.com/products/jasoncoon/wemos-d1-mini-esp8266-led-and-level-shifter-shield

posts.title: Post(1)
Post(2)
Post
3D printed, 8 inch, 30 sided rhombic tr
posts.content:
3D printed, 8 inch, 30 sided rhombic triacontahedron with 30 WS2811 RGB LEDs driven by a Wemos D1 Mini Pro.

This spherical piece plugs into a recessed lighting fixture and hangs from the ceiling by an adjustable length, cloth covered wire. It projects multi-colored light in all directions.

I printed the 30 faces in sets of two on my MP Select Mini, each set took about 2.5 hours to print. I need to take up mold making. :) I used white PLA filament. I glued and epoxied the pieces together into two halves, then used magnets to keep them together but still allow opening. The magnets in the pics haven't been glued, they're just temporary for now.

I'm debating on adding thin frosted plastic to each face for diffusion.

I'll try to add more build pics and details to the album below soon.

More pics: https://goo.gl/photos/B94uHHHujGrLGX568
More videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KFKj8UqcurI&index=2&list=PLUYGVM-2vDxK8WFg5BOkKtZHM2Xca_vib
Source code: https://github.com/evilgeniuslabs/bloom-v2

posts.title: Lately I_ve been having to approve a la
posts.content:
Lately I've been having to approve a large amount of posts before they show up here. It doesn't seem to be a G+ setting we have any control of. I haven't noticed any pattern whatsoever, it happens even on posts with no links. I don't always get a notification when new posts require approval. I'm checking as often as I can, but please be patient if your post doesn't show up right away.

I'm going to try to contact G+ support. I personally would rather have to remove a spam post every once in a while. I'm having to approve far more good posts than remove bad ones.

Thoughts?

posts.title: I_ve updated the ESP8266 FastLED Web Se
posts.content:
I've updated the ESP8266 FastLED Web Server example to include a palette selector. Here's the simpler version in master: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/commit/681c29a8776a40026a26365d3988dedd38526417

And here's the slightly more complicated version using the new dynamic field support in v1.1 (takes much less code): https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/commit/f04a089fa4e42ddaf2508ea8b2df793f0ab8410e

Not all of the patterns use the selected palette yet, and there are currently two different palette lists: "simple" ones like rainbow, cloud, forest, etc, and the gradient palette list from Mark's Palette Knife demos. I haven't decided if/how I want to combine them.

I wasn't able to figure out how to implement the palette list like the pattern list: as an array of structs with a palette and name. I tried several different approaches, but couldn't get any of them to compile. I'll admit I'm beyond my current C skill level. :) I ended up just using one array for the palettes, and another array for the names. It works, but it's not ideal: as the palette list grows, it'll be harder to keep the two arrays in sync.

Anyone have any ideas to get that to work? Compare the patterns list: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/blob/master/esp8266-fastled-webserver.ino#L274-L293 to the palettes list: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/blob/master/esp8266-fastled-webserver.ino#L297-L312

Thanks!

posts.title: Have you seen this, +Mark Kriegsman_! _
posts.content:
Have you seen this, +Mark Kriegsman?! I need to see this running FastLED! This is a strange, wonderful way to bring FastLED support to the Teensy 3.6. :)

For those of you that may not be aware, a while back Mark got FastLED running on an Apple //e: https://blog.kriegsman.org/2015/02/16/fastled-for-the-apple-ii/

posts.title: My application to exhibit at Maker Fair
posts.content: My application to exhibit at Maker Faire Kansas City has been accepted!  If you're in the area June 24 & 25th, stop by the dark room and say hello.  I'll be there all weekend "spreading the gospel" of FastLED.  :)  I should have at least a dozen pieces there, including several Fibonacci pieces, interactive RGB LED Pong, audio-reactive pieces, and my 6.5' tree.

posts.title: I_m working on an interactive and educa
posts.content:
I'm working on an interactive and educational FastLED project for the Maker Faire KC booth, and would appreciate any suggestions and feedback you can offer.

With what I had on-hand, I threw together two breadboards, each with a Teensy, three potentiometers, and a WS2812 ring. The potentiometers on one board are set to adjust RGB, and on the other adjust HSV.

They work great, but I don't think they'll be sturdy enough to last all weekend without getting destroyed. I created a PCB that will hopefully be a bit more sturdy.

I'd like to use high-quality, reliable components from reputable suppliers with good support, tutorials, and shipping. I went with 5mm NeoPixels, and a 5V Trinket Pro which won't need a level shifter. The non-pro Trinket is cheaper, but doesn't have enough analog inputs. I completely forgot about the 5V pin on the Teensy LC until I already had the board laid out. Maybe revision 2...

More details, code, and PCB files here: https://www.evilgeniuslabs.org/fastled-rgb-hsv-tutorial.html

I think this could be useful as a beginner project in a soldering & Arduino class/workshop. It'll be fully open source and open hardware.

Any suggestions, feedback, etc? Think this is a good educational project idea? Have any better ideas? Am I missing something that someone has already created?

Thanks!

posts.title: Preparations have begun for the booth!_
posts.content:
Preparations have begun for the booth! I picked up a 4' x 6' wire rack shelf for all my wall and ceiling hung pieces. Still need to mount whiteboard on the front of the shelves, behind the pieces. Nothing's final yet, feedback is most welcome.

I'll have several more pieces on tables, along with the interactive/educational ones.

Come see me at Maker Faire Kansas City on June 24 & 25 at Union Station: http://kansascity.makerfaire.com﻿

posts.title: +Justin Shaw over at WyoLum was kind en
posts.content:
+Justin Shaw over at WyoLum was kind enough to send me an ULTiM8x8 (actually an ULTiM8x24) set to play with! Of course I immediately got to work on it. I added some female headers, assembled it with a hex wrench, plugged in an Adafruit Feather ESP8266, and uploaded my FastLED ESP8266 Web Server app. It works and looks great! I created a couple of quick patterns just for the 8x24 matrix layout and shot a quick video.

More info on the ULTiM8x8: https://www.crowdsupply.com/maniacal-labs-wyolum/ultim8x8

Source code and more details: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/tree/ultim8x8

posts.title: I 3D printed a frame and mounted three_
posts.content:
I 3D printed a frame and mounted three ULTiM8x8 panels into a half cube. I have it fully 3D mapped, and have it scrolling noise and palettes in any direction!

If you'd like to build and play around with one of these, please consider supporting their crowd-funding campaign: https://www.crowdsupply.com/maniacal-labs-wyolum/ultim8x8

Code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/tree/ultim8x8
Frame: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2309657

*Disclaimer: I have backed the project, and they did send me a set to play with, but I have no other stake in this campaign.

posts.title: Having already built an educational pro
posts.content:
Having already built an educational project for Maker Faire Kansas City 2017, I wanted something a little more fun and interactive. So I picked up some LED Arcade buttons and built a little LED strip control box with them, using a Teensy 3.2 and a 74HCT245 level shifter (for the LED strip and arcade button LEDs). Currently using IR for changing modes and brightness, but plan to add more buttons to the side for that soon.

I plan to mount the control box to a table, and mount the LED strip a few feet away. The wooden box is pretty solid, and I’m hoping it can survive a weekend of constant abuse.

So far I have three interactive modes and three games (Color Invaders, Simon, and a color juggling game).

Let me know if you have any other ideas for me!

Build pics and more information: http://evlgeni.us/mfkc2017

Source code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/fastled-arcade

posts.title: I ordered a set of nine WS2812 rings a_
posts.content:
I ordered a set of nine WS2812 rings a while back (60, 48, 40, 32, 24, 16, 12, 8, 1), and finally got them mounted in a frosted glass and metal wall-hung lamp body. I 3D printed a frame for the LED rings, to keep each ring the same distance from the glass for even diffusion.

Since the outer ring has 60 LEDs, I plan to port over some clock patterns and NTP time sync soon, but for now I just have it running my ESP8266 FastLED WebServer sketch. I think Mark's Pride and ColorWaves patterns look amazing on it!

More info: https://www.evilgeniuslabs.org/psilocybe
Code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/tree/v1.1
Rings: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Mokungit-1-8-12-16-24-32-40-48-60-93-241-Bits-LEDs-WS2812B-SK6812/32789400837.html

posts.title: Finally got a cube assembled out of 6 U
posts.content:
Finally got a cube assembled out of 6 ULTiM8x8 (8x8 APA102) RGB LED panels by +Wyolum and +Maniacal Labs LLC! Got it 3D mapped and running on an ESP8266.

It's assembled using 3D printed corner brackets, hex nuts and bolts, and copper tape. The wires (5V, GND, DATA, CLK) run out of the bottom. Need to 3D print a base for it next.

Many thanks to +Justin Shaw and +Anool Mahidharia with Wyolum for the idea and all of the assistance!

ULTiM8x8: http://wyolum.com/ultim8x8/
Source Code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/tree/ultim8x8-cube

posts.title: Improved XYZ map and completed prototyp
posts.content:
Improved XYZ map and completed prototype stand for the ULTiM8x8 cube.

I reworked the map, switching from 8x8x8 to 10x10x10, which reduces the seams between panels. The old map, for example, treated all LEDs on one panel as X==0, and the first column of LEDS in the adjacent panel as X==0. The new map treats that same column of LEDs as X==1 instead.

The next stand prototype will rotate and have a shorter cylindrical base. I need to work on my 3D printer, I'm getting bad under-extrusion gaps and seams. Might be time for a new PTFE tube and/or nozzle. Been thinking about upgrading to a Bondtech extruder and Micro Swiss all metal hotend.

ULTiM8x8: http://wyolum.com/ultim8x8/
Source Code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp8266-fastled-webserver/tree/ultim8x8-cube

posts.title: via +PaulStoffregen_ https_twitter.co
posts.content:
via +PaulStoffregen: https://twitter.com/PaulStoffregen/status/943081758882381824

Little PCB using MAX485 for sending serial (including WS2812B / NeoPixel) data over long distances in noisy environments.

Thanks for sharing, Paul!

posts.title: After a long break, I_ve finally begun_
posts.content:
After a long break, I've finally begun working with the ESP32. Many thanks to +Sam Guyer and everyone who contributed to ESP32 support!

I've started on an ESP32 port of the FastLED WebServer project. It is still very much a work in progress, and I welcome anyone who would like to help:

https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp32-fastled-webserver

posts.title: First test of my 8x parallel output ESP
posts.content:
First test of my 8x parallel output ESP32 FeatherWing worked great!

This was with just 400 LEDs, I'll be testing with 800 tomorrow, and with 1,600 when my next order comes in! :)

Thanks to +Sam Guyer and everyone else that worked on this!

More info: https://www.evilgeniuslabs.org/level-shifter-featherwing
Source code: https://github.com/jasoncoon/esp32-fastled-webserver
Build pics: https://photos.app.goo.gl/Zx2mojHp2eQ4WCYg2
